comment.text: This translation key is used to display the length of a password in the user interface. It appears on a page where users can set and view the strength of their passwords, providing feedback on the number of characters in the input field.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The English phrase 'characters' is best translated as 'أحرف' (ahruf) rather than 'حرفًا' (harfan) when referring to a count. 'حرفًا' implies a single character.

The Azerbaijani translation "İşarələrin {{length}}" doesn't accurately convey the meaning of "characters" in the context of settings. 'İşarələrin' translates to 'of signs' or 'of indicators', which is not the intended meaning of character count.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Consider using "Simvolların {{length}}" (Simvolların - of symbols) or "Hərflərin {{length}}" (Hərflərin - of letters) for a more accurate translation, depending on the specific context.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The English term 'characters' is best translated as 'znaky' in this context, representing the number of characters in a text field or similar. While 'postavy' exists for 'characters' in the sense of people, 'znaky' is the appropriate term for this setting.

The English term 'characters' refers to the number of letters or symbols in a string, not just 'signs'. 'գրանշաններ' literally translates to 'signs' or 'marks' and doesn't accurately convey the intended meaning.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Consider using a more accurate translation such as "տողեր" (toger, meaning 'letters/characters') or "симвоլներ" (simvolner, meaning 'symbols'). The best option depends on the context.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The translation 'znak(i/ów)' is overly literal and not idiomatic Polish for 'characters' in this context. It indicates both singular and plural forms within the same word, which is awkward.  A more natural translation would be 'znaki'.
The singular form 'caractere' is used when the English uses 'characters'. Since the length is variable, the Romanian should use the plural form.

The Serbian translation "{{length}} знакова" is not the most natural or accurate translation of "{{length}} characters". While 'знакова' is grammatically correct for 'characters' (nominative plural), a more common and idiomatic phrasing would use 'каратера'.
The English 'characters' is best translated as 'karaktera' in Serbian (Latin) when referring to the length of text. 'Znakova' refers to 'signs' or 'symbols', which is not the intended meaning here.
The English phrase 'characters' is better translated as 'символів' (simvoliv) in the Ukrainian translation, which is the genitive case to match 'Символи:'
